conclusion: Power of External Force in a Rotating Conductor System in a Magnetic Field
Solve step by step to find the power of the external force doing work when the rod OC rotates in the magnetic field.
Identify the induced EMF due to motion in magnetic field
When the conductor rod OC rotates with angular velocity ω in a uniform magnetic field B, an EMF is induced according to Faraday's law.
Understand how the magnetic flux changes as the rod rotates.
The rod OC of length r (radius of the semicircle) sweeps out an area as it rotates.
The rate at which the area is swept gives us the rate of change of magnetic flux.

premise: The rod OC of length r sweeps out an area as it rotates.
conclusion: Area swept per unit time = (1/2) × r² × ω

premise: Area swept per unit time = (1/2) × r² × ω
conclusion: The induced EMF is: \( \mathcal{E} = B \times \frac{1}{2} \times r^2 \times \omega = \frac{1}{2}Br^2\omega \)
Calculate the current in the circuit
Using Ohm's law, the current in the circuit is: \( I = \frac{Br^2\omega/2}{R} = \frac{Br^2\omega}{2R} \)
Determine the magnetic force on the rod
The magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is: \( F = I \times L \times B \times \sin\theta \)
Where: I is the current, L is the length of the conductor (here, r), B is the magnetic field, θ is the angle between the current and the magnetic field
The force acts perpendicular to both the rod and the magnetic field.
Since the magnetic field is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of motion, this force will be tangential to the circular path and opposite to the direction of motion.
